comments.commentBody: My apologies for this post, my computer is malfunctioning and it was posted before editing.

Everyone of our politicians and media commentators who vote to oppose this deal should be outfitted with a uniform, a parachute and a gun and be the first to parachute into the war zone. That would be a fair price for the demagogueryAlmost all of the republicans in tonight's debate stated that America needs to lead. This agreement is leadership by America with China, France, Russia the UK plus Germany. Mike Huckabee complained we shouldn't make a deal with Iran, because they took American hostages. I notice that Germany and the UK were working together on this deal even thought they were once mortal enemies as were France and Germany and France and the UK.

May I gently interject that we no longer have a free press. Our founding fathers thought freedom of the press was fundamental to democracy. They were right. That is the reason Murdoch bought up as many news outlets as he could and that is why we are left with so few. The FCC just rolled over and played dead as "consolidation" - a fancy way of saying monopoly power - crushed journalism. It is now just another consumer product - full of hot air and no substance.

I was at the matinee yesterday because my partner won the last ticket in the lottery and so because he got in for $10, we could splurge on a full price ticket for me.  Perhaps because it was not Mr. Miranda in the role, there were a lot of  premium tickets available just before show time.  I was dead center and had a better seat than Bob Mackie or Teller (sans Penn) who sat further to my right.  It is AN INCREDIBLE experience but my partner and I both had great seats for well under $200.  It took some luck and I am grateful for it but you can get in without selling a semi-necessary organ.

I totally agree with this.  The clip here is really not representative of the show.  I was so excited to watch it (because I can't wait to see Hamilton again!) and was disappointed to find that it didn't recreate the magic of the play on stage.

Yes, by the people who will be singing Broadway songs in 25 years. No doubt people asked the same question about songs from "Oklahoma" when it first was heard.  The form is evolving and it is exciting to see a show that, like "Hair" or "A Chorus Line", pushes the (r)evolution forward.  Shows that have that kind of impact are rare but this is one of them.

I am not one for musicals, but when I saw this show at The Public, I started crying. It really is amazing, and as I tell my spouse, this is the future of theater in America, if theater in America wants to see another decade or two. Gone are the days of long ballads. In the Internet age, the world is smaller, more complex, more diverse and everyone is moving at lightning speed. We do not need to hear how Anna "tamed" the King b/c that story is dated and racist, even if the music is amazing!

I saw the show two months ago at the Public. Amazing. Innovative. Refreshing. Instructive. And engagingly entertaining. YES, there are many memorable lyrics and songs ("I am not throwing away my shot," for one.) from the musicals. And even if there weren't memorable, so what? (What an arbitrary and silly litmus test by which to judge the quality--and success--of a Broadway show.)

I cannot wait to see how many Tonys the musical wins, in addition to "Best Musical."

This show is going to bring as many or more demographic groups to Broadway as "Bring in da Noise, Bring in da Funk," and deservedly so!

Don't mind the "haters" or the typical "ol' Broadway fogeys." Go and see Hamilton now!!!!!

You obviously, totally, missed the point! It's not about blind casting! It's about appropriating American History from the white guys, the way we whites have appropriated black/Latino culture, but in a much more important way, the ideology and promise of this country.  It's such an important statement in the current climate of our country.

Besides being true to history, this show is nothing short of genius.
True Verona was worthy, but to take the formation of this nation and presenting it with today's style is brilliant!! You being underwhelmed is why there are rainbows. It would be a drag if we all liked the same color!

Saw HAMILTON last week and was underwhelmed. The 'newness' of it doesn't work for me. A musical with Latino and African American actors playing white characters singing in a contemporary manner? Didn't Mr. Brantley see (or know about) Two Gentlemen of Verona in the 70's? It won the Tony Award for Best Musical forty years ago! Granted it wasn't with rap music, but it was Shakespeare with rock music and that was the rap music of the time. The New York Shakespeare Festival began casting 'blind' decades ago. As for the history in HAMILTON, I'll give Mr. Brantley that. It is a good story. But Jonathan Groff steals the show, which is why it's criminal that he and the other principals don't get their own bows at the end. What are the creators afraid of, bigger applause for some and not the others? C'mob, that's show business!

You won't be disappointed. I attended the first preview after a very long day and a very long flight. I was exhausted, but I remember so much of the show, that says a lot. It's one of the most exciting things to ever happen on Broadway.

"Hamilton" is in my favorite theatre on Broadway. It's not large. There isn't a bad seat in it--and I've sat at the last row of the mezz on the wall before. Hint: (Rear orchestra is better than FRONT orchestra).
Says the Reaganite republican, who started discussion on civil right? Who stood up against the Russians in the Cuban Missle Crisis. He was also WWII war hero. The list of his achievements are endless

This comment by Yankee fan 'Mike' has nothing to do with "Hamilton." ????? Or the theater, or bringing forth thoughtful discussion about the content and reactions to the musical.
Why is it here ????

Still want to take him off the money?

If we need to replace someone's likeness on our money it should be Kennedy's on the 50 cent piece. It's terrible what happened to him but he really didn't deserve it based upon his meager record of accomplishments.
It's the real deal Joe. I was exhausted the night I saw it (the first preview) and I remember so much of it, it still amazes me. Better than "1776" and is not ALL rap and hip hop.

Oh ok then, thank you for the clarification! I do not myself speak Spanish, and so my searches were dependent on those online translation tools, which still have a long way to go. That must be why I failed to find the answer which you already knew from your actual exposure to the culture. Your explanation helped me to understand the way the phrase is used. For anyone reading this, please set aside my earlier concern about prejudicial overtones.

Mr Roth, although you are not completely wrong, neither are you completely right. The modern-Orthodox, at least some/many-?- of them HAVE come out against hate crimes and homophobia. Please try and find the link to the incredibly powerful and emotional speech by Rabbi Benny Lau, a cousin of the previous (Ashkenazi) Chief Rabbi Rav Yisrael Meir Lau.  He condemns both the attack on Shira Banks at the Gay Pride Parade, as well as the fire-bombing of the Palestinian family's house in the most clear and unequivocal terms. He is the Modern Orthodox Rabbi of a Jerusalem congregation. Also, Minister Naftali Bennett -also Modern Orthodox- has clearly condemned both attacks. I am not denying that there is racism in Israel-as in the US- or homophobia, but a large segment of the population clearly condemns it.  And "even" in Orthodox or Ultra-Orthodox circles, most people would never condone such violence against innocent people, even if they do not share the convictions of the more liberal or secular members of Israeli society.  And, as long as they do not spread hate, or advocate violence, they are entitled to their convictions-the price of a democracy and free society is that we have to uphold the right of every citizen to believe-or disbelieve- what they choose to, even if it is not an opinion we would agree with.

Omar, where or when did Israel ever disenfranchise the Arabs living in their own country?  They have the same rights as the Jews do when it comes to voting rights and running for political office, plus they can even serve in the IDF by volunteering for that.  As a matter of fact, if you followed the last Knesset election, the third largest party that stands there now happens to be Arabs not to mention that a lot of Arabs and Druze are given the right to be appointed as judges, ambassadors, or other government positions.  Please tell me if this is really the face of apartheid?  BTW, why did your country disenfranchise the Palestinians, who are practically the majority of the population?  More importantly, the Hashemites aren't even indigenous to Jordan at all, but are from Saudi Arabia, and the only reason they are in Jordan was after a power struggle with the Saud, who didn't want to share the land with them.  I would love to know why they couldn't just grant a Palestinian state with the stroke of a pen?  Also, Jordan is actually the majority of Palestine.  Even more ironic, there wasn't any reaction when the Hashemites responded to Palestinian extremists back in 1970 despite how much condemnation Israel responded to them.  BTW, they were secretly happy when Israel took back the West Bank after the Six Day War, because they didn't want to deal with the Palestinians anymore, and even gave up all claims after 1988.

It was a catechism test.

For instance, they didn't ask just how is it that the US spends more than $600 billion a year, more than the next twenty countries combined, and still has an allegedly underprepared and allegedly constantly weakening military? It was - do you subscribe as a matter of faith that the US military is underprepared and weak?

If one didn't, I doubt they'd be up there among the ten.

Absolutely!

I found the idea that the US is weak militarily to be completely absurd.

In fact, the military budget is enormous and devours resources we could be using to build our own nation.

Instead we get bleats about our supposed military weakness and declarations of war on the teacher's union.
It was a Conservative debate. They only had two hours for TEN candidates. You can wait for those debates much later.
The questions were about how well they hew to conservative ideology.  It was a series of litmus test questions.

Senator Goldwater addressed my Air War College class in 1974 (I was a colonel). The standard format was 45 minute talk, followed by a 45 question and answer session. He did not use notes, gave an an excellent talk, and answered all questions frankly. He was quite impressive and was two star general and political in the Reserves.

I voted for him in 1964, as I was an Eisenhower republican, but am now glad that lost. GWB miraculously converted me to a left wing socialist, by sending my son to Iraq for 27 months.

To give credit to Goldwater, he would not have invaded Iraq, but if he had, he would been been far more effective. Another point in his favor was that no patience or use for fanatical Bible thumpers. Barry was superior the entire slate of republicans in the primary.

You will be sorely missed.

Thanks for everything.
Where are Jon Stewart face masks available, that millions might express visually an enthusiasm for his integrity vs. the fraudulent Fox?

Now he belongs to the ages.

There's your victory, Fox. He'll be back. He'll be back, and he'll be millions.

Sounds like the Foxites only want their blonde babes to be babes and spout the company line. she's no intellectual heavyweight, but I give her great credit for calling out Trump. That said, I'm sure it only hardened support among the Trump fans.

Fox/Megan Kelly have really opened up my eyes about Trump. It is quite clear they are 100% for Bush.  Trump should run as an independent. I will vote for him more then ever now.  Fox news has lost there credibility.  Thanks Megan, for letting me see the light!

I've been following Fox News social media during and post debate and 90% of the people on there are going really angry with Fox/Megan Kelly and supporting Trump.  Their wrap up coverage may be trying to land Trump lost narrative but there is very different story taking place among their audience.
Kasich was indeed "surprising in a good way", but for Democrats! I'm sure the social conservatives didn't like what he had to say.

Most adult in the room: John Kasich.
Most reasonable: John Kasich.
Most dangerous: Scott Walker, a wolf in sheep's clothing who could actually pul off the masquerade all the way to Washington.

Well, I suppose if the President's role is to entertain the masses
But, if 'cute 'n' nasty pet tricks' had been allowed on stage it would have given him a run for his money.

Republican Debate: First off -- and I can't believe I'm about to say this -- the moderators asked some good, tough questions. Here's my take:

Most Invisible (tie): Ted Cruz and Ben Carson
Most Smooth: Marc Rubio
Most Angry: Donald Trump
Most Surprising (in a good way): John Kasich
Most Clueless & Scary: 10-way tie (just kidding, or am I?): Mike Huckabee
Most Policy-Wonk(y): Jeb Bush
Most Likely to Punch Someone (tie): Chris Christie and Rand Paul
Most Tired: Scott Walker
They are having six.

It was a catechism test.

For instance, they didn't ask just how is it that the US spends more than $600 billion a year, more than the next twenty countries combined, and still has an allegedly underprepared and allegedly constantly weakening military? It was - do you subscribe as a matter of faith that the US military is underprepared and weak?

If one didn't, I doubt they'd be up there among the ten.

I think Jennie Tourel was an expert with the songs of Reynaldo Hahn and think you will appreciate this rendition:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QZODIoarBzU
Thank you, Jon Stewart, for making it easier to live in a red state.
